'Kunitz domains' are the active domains of proteins that inhibit the function
of protein degrading enzymes or, more specifically, domains of Kunitz-type
protease inhibitors. They are relatively small with a length of about 50 to 60
amino acids and a molecular weight of 6 kDa. Examples of Kunitz-type protease
inhibitors are aprotinin (bovine pancreatic trypsin inhibitor, BPTI),
Alzheimer's amyloid precursor protein (APP), and tissue factor pathway
inhibitor (TFPI).

Standalone Kunitz domains are used as a framework for the development of new
pharmaceutical drugs.
